Fruits.name: Mango
Fruits.soil: Well-drained alluvial or loamy soil, pH 5.5–7.5
Fruits.fertilizers: NPK 1 kg/tree/year initially, increases with age
Fruits.required_items: Grafted plants, irrigation channels, pruning tools
process: Step 1: Site Selection – Choose frost-free, sunny locations with good drainage.
Step 2: Land Preparation – Dig pits 1×1×1 m, fill with FYM + soil mixture.
Step 3: Planting – Transplant grafted plants at spacing of 10×10 m.
Step 4: Irrigation – Water weekly for young plants, mature trees at longer intervals.
Step 5: Fertilization – Apply FYM + NPK during growing season, increase with age.
Step 6: Pruning & Training – Remove diseased/dry branches, maintain proper canopy.
Step 7: Pest Control – Use neem oil sprays for fruit flies and aphids.
Step 8: Harvesting – Fruits ready after 3–5 years, harvested when skin color changes and aroma develops.

Fruits.name: Banana
process: Step 1: Planting Material – Use tissue-cultured banana plants for better yield.
Step 2: Field Preparation – Dig pits of 60×60×60 cm, fill with compost + soil.
Step 3: Planting – Plant suckers/tissue plants at spacing 2×2 m.
Step 4: Irrigation – Frequent irrigation, avoid waterlogging.
Step 5: Fertilization – Apply FYM + NPK in 4–5 split doses.
Step 6: Propping – Support plants with bamboo poles during heavy bunch formation.
Step 7: Pest & Disease Control – Spray neem oil or bio-pesticides for aphids and leaf spot.
Step 8: Harvesting – Bunches ready in 11–12 months, harvest when fingers are plump and green.

Fruits.name: Apple
Fruits.required_items: Grafted saplings, support stakes, pruning tools
process: Step 1: Site Selection – Plant in temperate hilly areas with good chilling.
Step 2: Land Preparation – Dig pits 1×1×1 m, fill with compost + topsoil.
Step 3: Planting – Transplant saplings at 4×4 m spacing.
Step 4: Irrigation – Irrigate at critical stages (flowering & fruit set).
Step 5: Fertilization – Apply compost + NPK annually, increasing with tree age.
Step 6: Pruning – Essential for canopy shape and better fruit quality.
Step 7: Pest Control – Use neem sprays or traps for codling moth and aphids.
Step 8: Harvesting – Fruits harvested after 5–8 years, picked when skin color changes and fruits are firm.

Fruits.name: Guava
process: Step 1: Land Preparation – Plough land, dig pits (60×60×60 cm), fill with FYM + soil.
Step 2: Planting – Plant grafted saplings at spacing 5×5 m.
Step 3: Irrigation – Provide water weekly in summer, less in rainy season.
Step 4: Fertilization – Apply NPK annually before flowering.
Step 5: Pruning – Regular pruning to remove overcrowded branches.
Step 6: Pest Control – Neem oil or bio-pesticides against fruit fly.
Step 7: Harvesting – Fruits ready after 2–3 years, harvested at mature green stage.

Fruits.name: Grapes
Fruits.required_items: Vine stakes, trellis system, pruning tools
process: Step 1: Site Preparation – Install trellis or bower system for vine support.
Step 2: Planting – Use stem cuttings or grafts, spaced at 3×3 m.
Step 3: Training – Train vines on wires, prune for canopy balance.
Step 4: Irrigation – Irrigate during fruit development, reduce before harvest.
Step 5: Fertilization – FYM + NPK applied annually in split doses.
Step 6: Pest Control – Neem oil for mealy bugs and fungal sprays if needed.
Step 7: Harvesting – Bunches harvested after 2–3 years, when berries turn soft and sweet.

Fruits.name: Papaya
process: Step 1: Nursery Raising – Sow seeds in polythene bags or trays.
Step 2: Transplanting – Shift seedlings at 30–40 days to main field (spacing 2×2 m).
Step 3: Irrigation – Water every 10–15 days, avoid waterlogging.
Step 4: Fertilization – Apply FYM at planting, NPK in 3–4 splits.
Step 5: Weeding – Regular hand weeding required.
Step 6: Pest Control – Neem sprays against papaya mealybug.
Step 7: Harvesting – Fruits ready in 8–10 months when skin changes from green to yellow.

Fruits.name: Pomegranate
process: Step 1: Field Preparation – Dig pits 60×60×60 cm, fill with soil + FYM.
Step 2: Planting – Air-layered saplings planted at spacing 5×5 m.
Step 3: Irrigation – Provide water weekly, critical at flowering and fruiting.
Step 4: Fertilization – Apply FYM and NPK in split doses.
Step 5: Pruning – Regular pruning to maintain open canopy.
Step 6: Pest Management – Neem oil sprays against fruit borers and aphids.
Step 7: Harvesting – Trees start fruiting after 2–3 years, fruits picked when skin turns bright red.

Fruits.name: Strawberry
Fruits.soil: Sandy loam, rich in organic matter, pH 5.5–6.5
Fruits.required_items: Raised beds, mulching sheets, irrigation system
process: Step 1: Field Preparation – Prepare raised beds covered with plastic mulch.
Step 2: Planting – Transplant runners at spacing 30×30 cm.
Step 3: Irrigation – Use drip irrigation for better fruiting.
Step 4: Fertilization – Apply FYM + NPK in 2–3 splits.
Step 5: Mulching – Use straw or plastic to keep fruits clean.
Step 6: Pest Management – Neem oil sprays for aphids and mites.
Step 7: Harvesting – Fruits ready in 3–5 months, harvested when bright red and firm.

vegetables.name: Tomato
vegetables.soil: Well-drained loamy soil, rich in organic matter
process: Nursery raising: Sow seeds in raised beds or trays.
Transplanting: Shift 25–30 day-old seedlings at 60 × 45 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Water every 7–10 days; avoid waterlogging.
Staking: Tie plants to stakes for support.
Pruning: Remove side shoots to encourage main stem growth.
Fertilization: Apply manures before planting, split fertilizers at flowering and fruiting.
Plant protection: Spray against fruit borer and blight.
Harvesting: Pluck fruits when they turn red and firm.

vegetables.name: Carrot
vegetables.soil: Light sandy loam, deep and well-drained
vegetables.seeds: Improved varieties like Pusa Kesar, Nantes
process: Land preparation: Plough 2–3 times to make soil friable.
Sowing: Direct sowing of seeds in rows at 30 cm spacing.
Thinning: Remove extra seedlings to maintain spacing.
Irrigation: Water at 7–10 day intervals.
Weeding: Regular weeding to keep soil loose and aerated.
Fertilization: Apply FYM before sowing, top dress nitrogen after 30 days.
Plant protection: Monitor for leaf blight and nematodes.
Harvesting: Pull out roots when they reach full size and color.

vegetables.name: Spinach
vegetables.soil: Loamy soil rich in organic matter
vegetables.seeds: Local and improved varieties like All Green
process: Field preparation: Fine tilth with 2–3 ploughings.
Sowing: Direct sowing in rows at 30 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Water every 4–5 days in summer, 7–10 days in winter.
Weeding: Regularly weed and loosen soil.
Fertilization: Apply FYM before sowing, top dress nitrogen after 20 days.
Plant protection: Control leaf miners and downy mildew with sprays.
Harvesting: Pluck outer leaves 25–30 days after sowing, continue for 2–3 cuttings.

vegetables.name: Chili
vegetables.soil: Well-drained sandy loam, rich in organic matter
vegetables.seeds: Improved hybrids like Pusa Jwala, Tejaswini
process: Nursery raising: Sow seeds in raised beds.
Transplanting: Shift 40–45 day-old seedlings at 60 × 45 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Irrigate every 7–10 days.
Weeding: Keep beds weed-free.
Fertilization: Apply manures before planting, nitrogen in 3 splits.
Plant protection: Spray against thrips, mites, and leaf curl virus.
Harvesting: Pick green chilies at tender stage, red ones at full maturity.

vegetables.name: Onion
vegetables.soil: Fertile loamy soil with good drainage
vegetables.weather: Cool season for vegetative growth, dry weather for bulb maturity
vegetables.seeds: Improved varieties like N-53, Pusa Red
process: Nursery: Sow seeds in raised beds.
Transplanting: 45–50 day-old seedlings transplanted at 10 × 15 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Provide light irrigations at 8–10 day intervals.
Weeding: Regular hand weeding and hoeing.
Fertilization: Apply manures before transplanting, fertilizers in split doses.
Plant protection: Spray against thrips and purple blotch.
Harvesting: Bulbs harvested when tops fall over and dry.

vegetables.name: Cabbage
vegetables.soil: Well-drained sandy loam to clay loam soils
vegetables.seeds: Improved hybrids like Golden Acre, Pusa Mukta
process: Nursery: Sow seeds in raised beds.
Transplanting: 25–30 day-old seedlings transplanted at 60 × 45 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Irrigate at 10–15 day intervals.
Weeding: Regular weeding and earthing up.
Fertilization: Apply manures and fertilizers in split doses.
Plant protection: Control aphids, diamondback moth, and black rot.
Harvesting: Harvest heads when compact and firm.

vegetables.name: Cauliflower
vegetables.seeds: Varieties like Pusa Snowball, Early Kunwari
process: Nursery raising: Sow seeds in raised beds.
Transplanting: Shift seedlings at 45 × 45 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Water every 7–10 days.
Blanching: Cover curds with leaves to keep white.
Fertilization: Apply manures before transplanting, split fertilizer doses.
Plant protection: Spray against diamondback moth and leaf spot.
Harvesting: Harvest curds when firm, white, and compact.

vegetables.name: Brinjal
vegetables.soil: Well-drained loamy soil rich in organic matter
vegetables.seeds: Varieties like Pusa Purple Long, Arka Navneet
process: Nursery raising: Sow seeds in raised beds.
Transplanting: 30–35 day-old seedlings planted at 60 × 45 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Irrigate every 7–8 days.
Weeding: Regular weeding and hoeing.
Pruning: Remove side shoots and diseased plants.
Fertilization: Apply FYM before transplanting, split fertilizer doses later.
Plant protection: Spray against shoot and fruit borer, wilt.
Harvesting: Fruits harvested at tender stage before seeds harden.

cereals.name: Wheat
cereals.soil: Well-drained loamy or clay loam soils, rich in organic matter
cereals.weather: Cool season crop, requires 10°C–25°C, bright sunlight during grain filling
process: Land preparation: 2–3 ploughings and harrowing.
Sowing: Drill seeds in rows 20 cm apart.
Irrigation: Provide 4–5 critical irrigations at crown root initiation, tillering, booting, heading, and grain filling stages.
Weeding: Regular weeding and application of pre-emergence herbicide.
Fertilization: Apply FYM before sowing, fertilizers in split doses.
Plant protection: Control rusts, smut, and aphids.
Harvesting: Harvest when grains are hard and moisture is around 20%.

cereals.name: Rice
cereals.soil: Clayey loam, alluvial soils, requires good water retention
cereals.weather: Warm, humid climate, 20°C–35°C, needs standing water
process: Nursery raising: Sow seeds in wet nursery beds.
Transplanting: 20–25 day-old seedlings transplanted at 20 × 15 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Maintain 3–5 cm standing water during crop growth.
Weeding: Manual or mechanical weeding at 20 and 40 days after transplanting.
Fertilization: Apply manures before puddling, fertilizers in 3 splits.
Plant protection: Spray against stem borer, blast, and sheath blight.
Harvesting: Harvest when grains are hard and golden yellow.

cereals.name: Maize
process: Land preparation: Fine tilth with ploughing and harrowing.
Sowing: Direct sowing at 60 × 25 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Provide irrigation at knee-high, tasseling, silking, and grain filling stages.
Weeding: Manual or chemical weeding after 20 and 40 days.
Fertilization: Apply manures before sowing, split fertilizers at 3 stages.
Plant protection: Spray against stem borer, downy mildew.
Harvesting: Harvest cobs when husks dry and grains harden.

cereals.name: Barley
cereals.soil: Light loamy to sandy loam soils
process: Land preparation: 2–3 ploughings.
Sowing: Drill sowing in rows at 22 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Provide 2–3 irrigations at tillering and flowering stages.
Weeding: Manual or chemical weeding at 20–25 days.
Fertilization: Apply FYM before sowing, fertilizers at sowing and tillering.
Plant protection: Control aphids and powdery mildew.
Harvesting: Harvest when spikes turn golden yellow.

cereals.name: Millet
cereals.soil: Light sandy to loamy soils, drought tolerant
process: Land preparation: Ploughing and harrowing.
Sowing: Direct sowing at 45 × 15 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Mostly rainfed; irrigate at flowering if possible.
Weeding: Intercultural operations at 20 and 40 days.
Fertilization: Apply FYM before sowing, fertilizers at sowing.
Plant protection: Monitor for downy mildew and shoot fly.
Harvesting: Harvest when grains are hard and dry.

cereals.name: Oats
process: Land preparation: Fine tilth with 2–3 ploughings.
Sowing: Drill sowing in rows at 20 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Provide 3–4 irrigations during crop growth.
Weeding: Intercultural and weeding operations.
Fertilization: Apply manures before sowing, fertilizers in split doses.
Plant protection: Control rusts and aphids.
Harvesting: Harvest when panicles are mature and yellow.

cereals.name: Sorghum
cereals.soil: Sandy loam to clay soils, drought tolerant
process: Land preparation: Ploughing and harrowing.
Sowing: Direct sowing at 45 × 15 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Mostly rainfed; irrigate at flowering and grain filling stages if needed.
Weeding: Regular weeding at 20 and 40 days.
Fertilization: Apply manures before sowing, fertilizers in 2 splits.
Plant protection: Spray against shoot fly, stem borer, and smut.
Harvesting: Harvest when panicles are dry and grains are hard.

cereals.name: Ragi
cereals.soil: Loamy to clay loam soils, red soils
process: Nursery raising: Sow seeds in nursery beds.
Transplanting: 20–25 day-old seedlings at 25 × 10 cm spacing.
Irrigation: Provide irrigation at critical stages like tillering and grain filling.
Weeding: Intercultural operations at 20 and 40 days.
Fertilization: Apply FYM before sowing, fertilizers in 2 splits.
Plant protection: Monitor for blast disease and leaf spot.
Harvesting: Harvest when ear heads turn brown and grains are hard.

Pulses.name: Lentil
process: Select well-drained loamy soil with pH 6-7.
Plough 2–3 times to make a fine seedbed.
Sow seeds in rows with spacing of 30 cm between rows.
Provide light irrigation at flowering and pod formation stage.
Weed at 25–30 days after sowing.
Harvest when pods turn brown and dry under sun.
Pulses.soil: Loamy or clay loam soil, pH 6-7.
Pulses.fertilizers: 10–15 kg Nitrogen, 40–60 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Pulses.name: Chickpea
process: Prepare field by 2-3 ploughings followed by harrowing.
Sow seeds at 30 cm row spacing and 10 cm plant spacing.
Irrigate only 2–3 times during critical stages (flowering and pod formation).
Control weeds at 25–30 days after sowing.
Harvest when 90% of pods mature and plants turn yellow.
Pulses.soil: Sandy loam to clay loam with pH 6-8.
Pulses.fertilizers: 20 kg Nitrogen, 40 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Pulses.name: Green Gram
process: Select sandy loam soil with good drainage.
Prepare land by ploughing 2-3 times.
Sow seeds at 25 cm row spacing.
Weeding at 20–25 days after sowing.
Harvest when 80% pods mature and turn black.
Pulses.fertilizers: 15–20 kg Nitrogen, 40–50 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Pulses.name: Pigeon Pea
process: Deep ploughing before monsoon to prepare field.
Sow seeds with 60 cm row spacing.
Weed 2–3 times at regular intervals.
Irrigate at flowering and pod filling stage.
Harvest when pods turn brown and plants dry.
Pulses.soil: Well-drained loamy to black cotton soils.
Pulses.fertilizers: 20 kg Nitrogen, 40–60 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Pulses.name: Kidney Bean
process: Prepare fine seedbed with good drainage.
Sow seeds with 45 cm row spacing and 10 cm plant spacing.
Provide irrigation during flowering and pod setting.
Weed at 20–25 days after sowing.
Harvest when pods mature and dry.
Pulses.fertilizers: 20–25 kg Nitrogen, 40–60 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Pulses.name: Black Gram
process: Plough land and make seedbed.
Sow seeds at 30 cm row spacing.
Weed once at 20 days after sowing.
Irrigate during pod formation.
Harvest when pods turn black and dry.
Pulses.fertilizers: 15–20 kg Nitrogen, 40–50 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Pulses.name: Peas
process: Prepare field with 2-3 ploughings.
Sow seeds in rows 30 cm apart.
Irrigate at flowering and pod development stage.
Provide staking support for tall varieties.
Harvest when pods turn green and mature.
Pulses.fertilizers: 20 kg Nitrogen, 40–60 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Pulses.name: Horse Gram
process: Plough land 2–3 times for seedbed preparation.
Sow seeds by broadcasting or line sowing.
No irrigation needed, mostly rainfed crop.
Weed once at 20–25 days after sowing.
Harvest when pods turn brown and dry.
Pulses.soil: Poor, dry soils, even marginal lands.

Oilseeds.name: Mustard
process: Prepare well-ploughed seedbed with fine tilth.
Sow seeds in lines with 30 cm spacing between rows and 10 cm between plants.
Irrigate lightly after sowing and later during flowering and pod filling.
Weed once at 20-25 days after sowing.
Spray neem oil to control aphids and pests.
Harvest when 75% pods turn yellow and seeds are hard.
Oilseeds.soil: Well-drained loamy to sandy soils, pH 6–7.5.
Oilseeds.fertilizers: 40 kg Nitrogen, 30 kg Phosphorus, 20 kg Potash per hectare

Oilseeds.name: Sunflower
process: Plough the field 2-3 times for fine tilth.
Sow seeds at 60 cm row spacing and 30 cm plant spacing.
Apply irrigation at flowering and grain filling stage.
Weed at 20 days after sowing.
Control sucking pests using neem-based sprays.
Harvest when back of sunflower head turns yellow and seeds are firm.
Oilseeds.fertilizers: 40–60 kg Nitrogen, 40 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Oilseeds.name: Groundnut
process: Prepare sandy loam soil with 2-3 ploughings.
Sow seeds at 30 cm row spacing and 15 cm plant spacing.
Provide irrigation at pegging and pod formation stage.
Remove weeds at 20 and 40 days after sowing.
Apply gypsum to promote pod formation.
Harvest when leaves turn yellow and pods mature underground.
Oilseeds.fertilizers: 20–30 kg Nitrogen, 40–60 kg Phosphorus, 40–50 kg Potash per hectare

Oilseeds.name: Sesame
process: Prepare seedbed by 2–3 ploughings.
Sow seeds in rows 30 cm apart.
Weed at 20 days after sowing.
Provide irrigation during flowering and capsule formation stage.
Control leaf spot using neem sprays.
Harvest when leaves shed and capsules turn yellow.
Oilseeds.soil: Sandy loam to clay loam soils, pH 5.5–8.
Oilseeds.fertilizers: 25 kg Nitrogen, 40 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Oilseeds.name: Castor
process: Prepare deep well-ploughed soil before sowing.
Sow seeds at 90 cm spacing between rows and 60 cm between plants.
Apply irrigation during branching and flowering stage.
Weed 2–3 times at regular intervals.
Protect against leafhoppers using neem oil sprays.
Harvest when capsules dry and turn brown.
Oilseeds.soil: Black cotton soil and sandy loam, pH 6–8.
Oilseeds.fertilizers: 40 kg Nitrogen, 40 kg Phosphorus, 20 kg Potash per hectare

Oilseeds.name: Linseed
process: Plough land 2–3 times for fine tilth.
Sow seeds with 30 cm spacing between rows.
Provide irrigation at flowering and seed setting stage.
Weed once at 20–25 days after sowing.
Harvest when capsules turn brown and dry.
Oilseeds.soil: Loamy and clay soils with good drainage, pH 6–7.5.
Oilseeds.fertilizers: 20–25 kg Nitrogen, 40–50 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Oilseeds.name: Soybean
process: Prepare field with 2–3 ploughings and harrowing.
Sow seeds in rows 45 cm apart and 5 cm deep.
Apply irrigation during flowering and pod filling stage.
Weed twice at 20 and 40 days after sowing.
Protect crop from stem fly using neem oil sprays.
Harvest when pods turn yellow and leaves drop.
Oilseeds.fertilizers: 20–30 kg Nitrogen, 40–60 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Oilseeds.name: Safflower
process: Prepare land with 2–3 ploughings before sowing.
Sow seeds at 45 cm spacing between rows and 20 cm between plants.
Irrigate at flowering and seed development stages.
Weed twice during early crop growth.
Control aphids and caterpillars using neem sprays.
Harvest when flower heads dry and seeds harden.
Oilseeds.fertilizers: 40 kg Nitrogen, 40 kg Phosphorus per hectare

CashCrops.name: Sugarcane
process: Plough the field deeply 3–4 times to loosen the soil.
Apply FYM (farmyard manure) 20-25 tons per hectare before planting.
Plant setts (sugarcane cuttings) in furrows 1.2 meters apart.
Cover setts with soil and irrigate immediately.
Provide irrigation every 7–10 days during dry season.
Weed at 30, 60, and 90 days after planting.
Apply nitrogen, phosphorus, and potash fertilizers in split doses.
Control borers and aphids using neem-based sprays.
Harvest when cane is mature, usually 12-16 months after planting, when sugar content is high.
CashCrops.weather: Hot and humid, temperature 20–30°C, annual rainfall 1000–1500 mm.
CashCrops.soil: Deep, fertile loamy soil with good drainage, pH 6–7.5.
CashCrops.fertilizers: 150 kg Nitrogen, 60 kg Phosphorus, 60 kg Potash per hectare

CashCrops.name: Coffee
CashCrops.duration: 3-4 years to first harvest, economic yield up to 25 years
process: Select shaded slopes in high-rainfall areas for plantation.
Prepare pits (45x45x45 cm) filled with compost and soil mixture.
Plant coffee seedlings at the onset of monsoon with 2m spacing.
Provide shade trees to protect from direct sunlight.
Weed regularly and mulch soil to conserve moisture.
Irrigate lightly during dry months.
Prune plants annually to maintain shape and productivity.
Control berry borer and leaf rust with neem sprays.
Harvest ripe red berries by hand picking and process by pulping, fermentation, and drying.
CashCrops.weather: Cool, humid climate with 1500–2500 mm rainfall, temperature 15–25°C.
CashCrops.soil: Well-drained loamy soil, rich in organic matter, pH 6–6.5.
CashCrops.fertilizers: 40–50 kg Nitrogen, 30 kg Phosphorus, 30 kg Potash per hectare

CashCrops.name: Tea
CashCrops.duration: 3-4 years to first plucking, economic yield up to 40 years
process: Select hilly slopes with good rainfall and drainage.
Prepare pits (45x45x45 cm) filled with topsoil and compost.
Plant tea seedlings or cuttings at spacing of 1.2m × 0.75m.
Provide shade and windbreaks for young plants.
Weed and mulch regularly to conserve soil moisture.
Apply fertilizers in 4–5 split doses per year.
Prune bushes every 3–4 years to maintain plucking table.
Pluck tender leaves and buds every 7–15 days.
Process harvested leaves by withering, rolling, fermenting, drying, and grading.
CashCrops.weather: Humid climate with 150–300 cm rainfall, temperature 20–30°C.
CashCrops.fertilizers: Nitrogen-rich fertilizers (50–60 kg N per hectare annually)

CashCrops.name: Tobacco
process: Prepare well-ploughed seedbed and sow tobacco seeds in nursery.
Transplant seedlings to main field after 35–40 days.
Maintain spacing of 60x45 cm between plants.
Apply fertilizers in 3 split doses.
Weed twice during early growth stages.
Irrigate lightly and avoid waterlogging.
Remove flower heads to encourage leaf growth.
Harvest mature leaves when they turn yellow-green.
Cure leaves in shade or smoke houses for proper quality.
CashCrops.seeds: Tiny seeds (0.5 g per hectare nursery)
CashCrops.fertilizers: Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Potash in balanced doses

CashCrops.name: Cotton
process: Prepare soil by deep ploughing and harrowing.
Sow treated seeds at 75x30 cm spacing.
Provide irrigation at flowering and boll formation.
Weed 2–3 times during early crop stage.
Spray neem oil against bollworm and sucking pests.
Apply fertilizers in split doses for better yield.
Harvest cotton bolls when fully mature and burst open.
CashCrops.weather: Warm climate, temperature 20–30°C, requires 600–1200 mm rainfall.
CashCrops.soil: Black cotton soils and alluvial soils, pH 6–8.
CashCrops.fertilizers: 60–80 kg Nitrogen, 30–40 kg Phosphorus, 30–40 kg Potash per hectare

CashCrops.name: Rubber
CashCrops.duration: 6-7 years to first tapping, productive life 25-30 years
process: Select high rainfall, humid areas for plantation.
Prepare pits (75x75x75 cm) with soil and compost mixture.
Plant budded stumps or seedlings with 7x7 m spacing.
Maintain shade trees and cover crops in early years.
Weed and mulch regularly.
Apply fertilizers in split doses annually.
After 6–7 years, start tapping trees by making diagonal cuts in bark.
Collect latex in cups and process into sheets or blocks.
CashCrops.weather: Hot and humid climate with 2000–3000 mm rainfall, 25–35°C.
CashCrops.soil: Deep well-drained lateritic or alluvial soils, pH 4.5–6.5.
CashCrops.fertilizers: Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Potash in split doses

CashCrops.name: Jute
process: Prepare field with 3–4 ploughings for fine tilth.
Sow seeds by broadcasting or in rows 25 cm apart.
Thin seedlings to maintain 10 cm spacing.
Weed once at 20–25 days after sowing.
Apply fertilizers in 2–3 split doses.
Irrigate as needed during dry periods.
Harvest plants at 120–150 days when they are 2–3 m tall.
Ret the harvested plants in water for fiber extraction.
CashCrops.weather: Hot and humid climate, 24–35°C, rainfall 1500–2000 mm.
CashCrops.soil: Alluvial soils rich in organic matter, pH 6–7.5.
CashCrops.fertilizers: 40 kg Nitrogen, 20 kg Phosphorus, 20 kg Potash per hectare

CashCrops.name: Indigo
process: Prepare soil by ploughing and leveling.
Sow seeds at onset of monsoon with row spacing 30 cm.
Weed once at 20–25 days after sowing.
Apply organic manures to boost leaf growth.
Irrigate lightly during dry periods.
Harvest crop when plants are 1–2 m tall and full of leaves.
Process by fermenting plants in vats for dye extraction.
CashCrops.weather: Warm and humid climate, temperature 20–30°C, rainfall 1000–1500 mm.
CashCrops.soil: Light loamy soils with good drainage, pH 6–7.5.
CashCrops.fertilizers: Low requirement – 20 kg Nitrogen, 20 kg Phosphorus per hectare

Spices & Herbs.name: Chili
Spices & Herbs.soil: Well-drained loamy or sandy soil, pH 6–7
Spices & Herbs.required_items: Irrigation system, seedling trays, organic pesticides
process: Step 1: Seed Selection – Choose hybrid, disease-resistant chili varieties.
Step 2: Nursery Preparation – Prepare seedbeds, treat seeds with Trichoderma for fungal protection.
Step 3: Transplanting – After 25–30 days, transplant seedlings with spacing 45×30 cm.
Step 4: Field Preparation – Plough field, apply compost (5–6 tons/acre), irrigate before transplanting.
Step 5: Fertilization – Apply basal dose of FYM + NPK, follow top-dressing with urea after flowering.
Step 6: Irrigation – Light irrigation every 8–10 days; avoid waterlogging.
Step 7: Weed & Pest Control – Mulching or hand weeding; spray neem oil for aphids/mites.
Step 8: Harvesting – Harvest green chilies after 70–80 days; red chilies after drying on plant.

Spices & Herbs.name: Coriander
process: Step 1: Soil Preparation – Plough and harrow field; add compost or FYM (2 tons/acre).
Step 2: Seed Treatment – Crush coriander seeds lightly into halves for better germination.
Step 3: Sowing – Sow directly in rows with spacing 30 cm apart.
Step 4: Irrigation – Light irrigation immediately after sowing, then at 10–15 day intervals.
Step 5: Fertilization – Apply small doses of nitrogen after 30 days of growth.
Step 6: Weeding – Perform hand weeding twice during crop growth.
Step 7: Harvesting – Harvest green leaves at 30–40 days, seeds at 90 days.

Spices & Herbs.name: Mint
Spices & Herbs.soil: Moist, loamy soil rich in organic matter
Spices & Herbs.required_items: Irrigation channels, organic sprays, harvesting knife
process: Step 1: Propagation – Use root suckers or stolons instead of seeds.
Step 2: Field Preparation – Add compost (8–10 tons/acre), plough, and level field.
Step 3: Planting – Plant root suckers at 30×30 cm spacing.
Step 4: Irrigation – Requires frequent irrigation every 7–10 days.
Step 5: Fertilization – Apply FYM at sowing, NPK as top-dressing during vegetative growth.
Step 6: Weed & Pest Management – Mulching controls weeds; spray neem oil for pests.
Step 7: Harvesting – Cut leaves 3–4 times during season, starting at 90 days.

Spices & Herbs.name: Turmeric
Spices & Herbs.soil: Fertile loamy or alluvial soil, pH 5–7
process: Step 1: Land Preparation – Plough land 3–4 times, make raised beds.
Step 2: Seed Selection – Select healthy rhizomes, treat with fungicides or Trichoderma.
Step 3: Planting – Place rhizomes 5–7 cm deep, spacing 30×20 cm.
Step 4: Mulching – Apply green leaves or straw mulch after planting.
Step 5: Irrigation – Provide light irrigation every 7–10 days.
Step 6: Fertilization – Apply FYM + NPK in split doses after 45 and 90 days.
Step 7: Weed & Pest Control – Hand weeding, apply neem oil or bio-fungicides.
Step 8: Harvesting – After 8–9 months when leaves turn yellow, dig out rhizomes and cure.

Spices & Herbs.name: Black Pepper
Spices & Herbs.soil: Well-drained loamy soil, rich in organic matter
process: Step 1: Propagation – Use rooted cuttings of high-yielding varieties.
Step 2: Planting – Plant near support trees/poles at 2×2 m spacing.
Step 3: Manuring – Apply compost + NPK twice yearly.
Step 4: Training & Pruning – Guide vines onto supports, prune excess branches.
Step 5: Irrigation – Provide light irrigation during dry months.
Step 6: Pest Control – Use neem-based sprays against root grubs and mealy bugs.
Step 7: Harvesting – Pepper spikes harvested when berries turn red; dried to produce black pepper.

Spices & Herbs.name: Cardamom
Spices & Herbs.soil: Forest loamy soil, rich in humus
process: Step 1: Site Selection – Grows best under forest shade.
Step 2: Propagation – Divide rhizomes into clumps and plant.
Step 3: Planting – Space 2×2 m apart, provide adequate shade.
Step 4: Mulching – Apply leaf mulch for moisture retention.
Step 5: Fertilization – Apply compost and NPK in 2–3 split doses.
Step 6: Irrigation – Light irrigation needed during summer.
Step 7: Pest Management – Use bio-pesticides against thrips and borers.
Step 8: Harvesting – After 2–3 years, capsules harvested every 30–40 days.

Spices & Herbs.name: Clove
Spices & Herbs.soil: Rich loamy soil with good drainage
process: Step 1: Nursery – Raise seedlings from fresh clove seeds.
Step 2: Planting – Transplant seedlings at 2–3 years into field at 6×6 m spacing.
Step 3: Fertilization – Apply compost + NPK annually.
Step 4: Irrigation – Water young plants regularly, mature trees occasionally.
Step 5: Mulching – Apply organic mulch around trees.
Step 6: Pest Control – Spray neem oil for leaf-eating pests.
Step 7: Harvesting – After 6–7 years, harvest unopened flower buds (cloves).

Spices & Herbs.name: Fenugreek
process: Step 1: Soil Preparation – Plough land, add compost or FYM (2 tons/acre).
Step 2: Sowing – Directly sow seeds in rows with 30 cm spacing.
Step 3: Irrigation – Light irrigation after sowing, then every 10–12 days.
Step 4: Fertilization – Apply small doses of nitrogen at 30 days.
Step 5: Weed Management – Hand weeding at 20 and 40 days.
Step 6: Pest Control – Spray neem oil to control aphids.
Step 7: Harvesting – Harvest leaves at 30–40 days, seeds at 100 days.
